unnormalised: **Quora Post: Builder Reviews - Real Estate & Property**
normalised: **Quora Post: Builder Reviews - Real Estate and Property**

unnormalised: Hey everyone! Thinking about buying property in Bangalore or maybe even Pune? One thing I've learned the hard way is the absolute necessity of checking builder reviews *before* you even think about handing over your booking amount.
normalised: Hey everyone! Thinking about buying property in Bangalore or maybe even Pune? One thing I've learned the hard way is the absolute necessity of checking builder reviews *before* you even think about handing over your booking amount.

unnormalised: Seriously, don’t just fall for the fancy brochures and promises of 'luxury living' like I almost did with Sunshine Builders back in 2018. The floor plan looked great, the location in Whitefield was perfect, but their reputation was…let’s just say less than stellar.
normalised: Seriously, don’t just fall for the fancy brochures and promises of 'luxury living' like I almost did with Sunshine Builders back in two thousand and eighteen. The floor plan looked great, the location in Whitefield was perfect, but their reputation was…let’s just say less than stellar.

unnormalised: I stumbled across some really detailed reviews online about their delayed possession (think delays stretching over 2 years!), shoddy construction quality (leaks during the monsoons!), and poor customer service. Imagine dealing with that after investing your hard-earned Rs. 75 lakhs!
normalised: I stumbled across some really detailed reviews online about their delayed possession (think delays stretching over two years!), shoddy construction quality (leaks during the monsoons!), and poor customer service. Imagine dealing with that after investing your hard-earned rupee seventy five lakhs!

unnormalised: My advice? Don't rely solely on the builder's marketing materials. Look for independent review sites, check forums, and even talk to people living in their existing projects. Go beyond just a superficial Google search. Dig deep. Also, see if there are any RERA complaints registered against them. That's a major red flag!
normalised: My advice? Don't rely solely on the builder's marketing materials. Look for independent review sites, check forums, and even talk to people living in their existing projects. Go beyond just a superficial Google search. Dig deep. Also, see if there are any R E R A complaints registered against them. That's a major red flag!

unnormalised: Specific things to look for in reviews: Are they delivering on time? Are the common areas well maintained *after* the initial handover (this is a big one!)? How responsive are they to complaints and defects? Are they following the promised specifications or cutting corners? Remember to cross-reference info!
normalised: Specific things to look for in reviews: Are they delivering on time? Are the common areas well maintained *after* the initial handover (this is a big one!)? How responsive are they to complaints and defects? Are they following the promised specifications or cutting corners? Remember to cross-reference info!

unnormalised: Someone I know almost bought a flat from "Dream Homes" in Mumbai. They were promised possession by 30/06/2023 but guess what? It’s still under construction as of today! Possession is now pushed to sometime in 2025, and they got a notice to pay additional charges on 05/11/2024 at 14:00 hrs.
normalised: Someone I know almost bought a flat from "Dream Homes" in Mumbai. They were promised possession by thirtieth june two thousand and twenty three but guess what? It’s still under construction as of today! Possession is now pushed to sometime in two thousand and twenty five, and they got a notice to pay additional charges on fifth november two thousand and twenty four at two P M.

unnormalised: Even if a project is well underway (say, 5 km from your workplace and tempting), don’t be swayed by the “almost done” appeal. Due diligence is key! Good luck finding your dream home! And don’t forget to consult with a good advocate – especially before signing any agreements at 10:00 AM!
normalised: Even if a project is well underway (say, five kilometer from your workplace and tempting), don’t be swayed by the “almost done” appeal. Due diligence is key! Good luck finding your dream home! And don’t forget to consult with a good advocate – especially before signing any agreements at ten A M!
